reviewText: This is yet another awesome game in the Total War series.  All total war games are worth purchasing in my opinion, but this one in particular was the first total war to truly introduce the use of large scale firearms as apposed to melee combat.  The game looks very nice, and like all modern Total War games it has an extensive modding community that can increase your overall enjoyment of the game.   I highly suggest you buy this game.

reviewText:
The only and best line battle simulator on the Steam store :P

Variety of factions to play from including five Native Tribes: Iriquois, Pueblo, Cherokee, Plains, and Huron Wyndot. Not to mention the fierce Ottoman Empire

Authentic and detailed naval battles and simulation for those classic wooden, sail, and cannon warships used in the 18th century

Active multiplayer community

Plenty of interesting and relevant quotes in the loading screens; loading screens are beautiful too

Graphics still hold up for a 2009 game

Though, the AI runs away constantly in the Warpath campaign, and siege battles become redundant as the AI won't utilize the walls. Also note, some people like to spam artillery and light dragoons and light infantry, resulting in hit and run

Recommend at base price or bundles that include all the DLC

reviewText: A step forward for the series, Empire still has some rathe obvious flaws that play-testing would have easily highlighted, including a lack of Swiss nation or even region and the insistance that some nations are Major and some Minor, that a single state United States is more important to the two state Venetians is sad.  The DLC is pointless and overpriced, the game insists on a very European-centric perspective and the game does crash occasionally, but it is worth buying when on sale.

reviewText: I am an American, and purchased this while living in Europe. I have spent hours upon hours lost in this game world. It was for me such an amazing experience - my introduction to Steam, the introduction of sea battles in the Total War franchise, the historical period.\n\nIt was a step down in some aspects - the clone" armies vs the unique variations in Medieval II (my favorite Total War to date)
recommended: but the sheer scope and size of it all is absolutely fan-f-ing-tastic. This Total War was the first one that really gave me the feeling of being in control of an alternate history; the leader of a world power.\n\nOne of the things that I miss a bit was the length of the battles. It's sad to go into a game of the wonderful Attila
hoursPlayed: such a step up from Rome II (which almost brought me to tears at launch it was so disappointing)
voteText: and have two massive armies decimate each other in 10 minutes. I played Empire last night
votesHelpful: and the battle lasted 45 minutes. Half-way through the battle my teammate and I were winning
votesTotal: and then the French overpowered my overly aggressive enemy without me noticing while I defended against the Cherokee
votesFunny: and in the last 10 minutes our enemies completely overcame us. Such a lengthy
commentsCount: brutal battle is typical in Empire
column16: while most confrontations in Rome II and Attila seem like 10-minute-long skirmishes. +1 for Empire: TW.\n\nSieges too were a bit disappointing with focus on forts vs towns
column17: but the towns you do get to fight in usually make for exciting urban combat situations.\n\nOverall
column19: but heads-and-shoulders above anything else out there for this time period. Thank you Creative Assembly - you're not perfect
column20: but your games have been my favorite for over a decade."

reviewText:
This is a great entry into the total war franchise.
- - - - pros
- very balanced
- good unit variety
- deep strategic possibility s
- easy to learn hard to master
- - - - cons
-very rock paper scissors when you go unit to unit
-  laggy online
- no longer has a bustling player base
- units moral seems really fragile
- - - -wishes
- steam mod support

This game takes place in the colonial era. So guns play a rather large role in this, and because of the era the guns are mostly single shot muzzle loaders. There are also melee infantry, hoursemen (both armed with fire arms and melee weapons) , and artillery of varying caliber.

Landscape is very important in this game because of the surplus of ranged units. Hight as in most games will help your ranged units and slow the advance of melee infantry. Artillery is also helped by being put on hills and the like.

In all honesty melee is not as important in this game as in others. But melee troops are still very useful. Because most units are ranged a melee unit can very quickly destroy their moral or the unit in general. But this goes the same both ways because of the ranged unit being well ranged. So melee are best for ambushes or holding walls.

One of the cons i mentioned above is that moral seems really fragile. Units can brake in a mater of SECONDS. This would be ok if it was mere cannon fodder but even the most elite of units can be broken after one or two volleys of fire then at other times they charge though no problem. The moral system seems unstable and inconstant.  -1 point

As mentioned above all the factions are relatively balance because they share alot of units with small changes. The only faction that is at both a disadvantage and an advantage is the Indian nations. Because they are over all more stealthy they are good for ambushes, they also have better melee units from the start of the game, but their range is a lot lower then the European nations.

The online is very laggy if more then two players are involved. This is rather common in total war games. So unless playing 1 on 1 online or playing though LAN i would recommend not putting your hopes into online -.5 points
A small complaint i also have is the lack of online campaign. Many other total war games both before and after have this feature.

As mentioned above the unit to unit comparison is very rock paper scissors. But many strategy games are like this and with proper strategy and high ground advantage it can be changed.
so because you can counter it I think it evens out.
so over all i think it is a 8.5/10

reviewText:
You see, I bought the elite pack which contains the DLC and original game, although it was a bit pricey...

Anyways, back to the game. Empire is quite different from the other games in the series because it allows Naval Battles! On this unique experience, you control your army on the 7 seas, versing A.I. or real people online or locally. It can get quite intense, as your ships may flee if damaged, but there are also contreversol wins!

The game also allows you to (as I mentioned earlier) to play online with friends, or random people. The problem with online matches though, is that if your internet is bad, you must drop from the game. This can lead to frustraion from the opposing player. You can also do quick Naval or Land matches (Although, finding a game in the quick section is difficult.) You can team up and join an alliance in online matches too! They are quite intense! I prefer playing with friends, 'cause im so good at the game and I beat them :3.

The Total War Series has never been known for graphics, but I have to say this game suprises me. My favourite part is seeing my men run into my enemy and watch the battle. You can see them have little battles with eachother! It looks quite realistic, as after the batttle you can see all the dead men that have fought.

Overall this game is meant for RTS players who enjoy a good online battle. This game is simple to manuver and comprehend. This is my favourite out of the Total War series (personally.) Overall, It definately fed my hunger for a good bloodbath and RTS game. I give it a 8.5/10!

reviewText:
Unlike what some people might say, this magnificent title is a masterpiece any gamer should add to their collection. Unlike some third-person RTS games, this one is a step up from the rest, taking grand historical campaigns, epic clashes between armies, and real one-of-a-kind strategy and throwing it into something that I can only describe as being as awesome as Morga Freeman, Chuck Norris, and Bill Gates being in a free for all underwater cage match with a narwhale... in space.
I personally enjoy just building up my forces, taking up a strategic formation, and watching as my helpless opponents flee from my massive and, cunning, and not to say extremely boss-like infantry.
The only thing that would honestly make this game better is if you could assign PSY, the Korean rapper who invented Gangnam Style, to lead your ranks into battle with his incredibly Swagtasticerific dance moves and a world class marching band with guns trailing behind him.

-10 out of 10 out of 10 :D

reviewText:
One of the best (only beaten by Medieval II) Total War games in the series. The graphics, both in the strategic view and battle view are excellent. The gameplay is smooth and its friendly to new players, offering all necessary tutorials. The only gripe with the game IMHO, is that it ends, there should be a continuous campaign, as each turns takes quite a large chunk of time, obviously it has to take building times into account etc but the campaigns are so engaging and perfectly crafted that they should be able to played without an end date.
9.5/10 , missing that .5 for ending.

Buy it.

reviewText:
I completely recommend this game. It's already a few years old, so I would advise to wait for a sale perhaps... but considering that I have spent that many hours on Steam playing this game (and many hours off-Steam as well), even paying the full price does not mean you'll feel ripped off. You're not only buying quite a lot of game with your purchase, you're also buying the best single-player experience any Total War can bring you.

Total War is a series that combines the most massive and spectacular battles you will find in any game with the building and managing of an empire in single player. In multiplayer it's the best game of chess you can have. This particular Total War is set in the early Modern Age (1700-1800), and for the first time includes line-infantry with muskets as the backbone of an army and not a melee unit, which makes for a unique Total War. In this era, the European countries were involved in a lot of wars with eachother while they conquered several continents and established trade routs with most of the rest of the world, and I do not know of any other media that encompasses that much of this era like in Empire: Total War.

From my point of view, this is the last of the true and classic Total War games. I have played every Total War (including Shogun) and my favorites are Rome 1 (not rome 2, absolutely not rome 2) because of the way it represents the classical era, Empire because I am personally very interested in this era as well and it is unique in the ranged combat with muskets and I love Shogun 2, because it simply has the best multiplayer. There is also a stand-alone expansion of Empire about the conquests of Napoleon, something I had been anticipating for many years, but I didn't like it enough. It's too limited. I also don't appreciate a lot from the medieval era in general. It's chaotic, it's too religious/christian, there is no progress, there is death, decay, famine and the plague and Medieval Total War games represent this fine, I don't like it.

Why do I consider this the last Classic Total War? Well, Total War is a game that, as you play, can teach you stuff. Like in Rome1 you learn that clear glass was invented, in Empire you get info along the way about what happened in the 18th century and it was a lot. In fact, the only good description I can find about my 'religion', Secular Humanism, I found in Empire Total War. This is also the last Total War in which the campaign map is open, you can send your armies where you want and you're not stuck in corridors like in the latest installments. However, it is the first Total War to include a tech-tree and naval battles (and naval battles were very spectacular in this era!).

The 3 continents you can explore with armies and conquer are Europe, North and Middle America and the Indian sub-continent (you can walk from Western-Europe to India if you please, or sail around Africa). There are also a few trade regions to conquer using just the navy: the east coast of South-America, the west coast of Africa, the strait of Madagaskar and the East-Indies. Every region has it's own feel and it's own enviroments, cultures, empires and people.

The units you command are also unique for each culture. Yes, warfare was a lot about standing in lines facing eachother firing lead balls back and forth and then reloading for quite some time, the native americans for instance are better equiped for guerilla style battles combining melee with light infantry equipes with muskets or bow and arrow. Along the tech-tree you unlock new units to build and command, artillery changes from simple big cannons to a whole specrum of weaponry. Ranging from mortars to puckle-guns (rapid fire musket, very early machinegun) and stuff in between. Cavalry also comes in many flavors, dragoons that melee on horseback but function as line infantry dismounted, full melee cavalry and the cavalry even gains horsedrawn cannons as technology is invented. And the ships! Oh man, imagine the big ships of the line with over 40 cannons on each broadside, 2 lines come within eachothers range... just crank up the sound to really loud!

Like most Total War games, the game has improved a lot because of mods, Empire is no exception. Even for new players I would recommend to install and use at least Darth Mod, which can be found in the Steam Workshop. More units are also available with mods, but I'm not sure which one to recommend. But the Darth Mod really improves the ai and the feel of the game.

Every Total War has it's own features and it's own feel to it. Personally I find this installment the best in single-player of the entire series. I have had some really tight battles in the campaign. In Empire it is possible to position your men in some buildings, so making a last stand gets it's own feeling to it. Your men firing from the windows at incoming soldiers while your lines of infantry try to hold the lines in front of that building, untill the fight turns melee when the bayonets are pointed at eachother.

And I haven't even mentioned the historical battles that come with each Total War, you can reenact battles that actually took place and with a historically similar setting and armies to command. Pitching you as Washington vs the Brittish and many others. There is a demo available here on Steam, in it you can play at least one of these historical battles and get a glimpse of what is in store for you when it comes to battles, but if you like games like Civilization or RTS games like Age of Empires and you haven't tried Total War at all, you will love it!

This is also the last Total War in which the campaign map is open, you can send your armies where you want and you're not stuck in corridors like in the latest installments. However, it is the first Total War to include a tech-tree and naval battles (and naval battles were very spectacular in this era!).

The 3 continents you can explore with armies and conquer are Europe, North and Middle America and the Indian sub-continent (you can walk from Western-Europe to India if you please, or sail around Africa). There are also a few trade regions to conquer using just the navy: the east coast of South-America, the west coast of Africa, the strait of Madagaskar and the East-Indies. Every region has it's own feel and it's own enviroments, cultures, empires and people.

The units you command are also unique for each culture. Yes, warfare was a lot about standing in lines facing eachother firing lead balls back and forth and then reloading for quite some time, the native americans for instance are better equiped for guerilla style battles combining melee with light infantry equipes with muskets or bow and arrow. Along the tech-tree you unlock new units to build and command, artillery changes from simple big cannons to a whole specrum of weaponry. Ranging from mortars to puckle-guns (rapid fire musket, very early machinegun) and stuff in between. Cavalry also comes in many flavors, dragoons that melee on horseback but function as line infantry dismounted, full melee cavalry and the cavalry even gains horsedrawn cannons as technology is invented. And the ships! Oh man, imagine the big ships of the line with over 40 cannons on each broadside, 2 lines come within eachothers range... just crank up the sound to really loud!

Like most Total War games, the game has improved a lot because of mods, Empire is no exception. Even for new players I would recommend to install and use at least Darth Mod, which can be found in the Steam Workshop. More units are also available with mods, but I'm not sure which one to recommend. But the Darth Mod really improves the ai and the feel of the game.

Every Total War has it's own features and it's own feel to it. Personally I find this installment the best in single-player of the entire series. I have had some really tight battles in the campaign. In Empire it is possible to position your men in some buildings, so making a last stand gets it's own feeling to it. Your men firing from the windows at incoming soldiers while your lines of infantry try to hold the lines in front of that building, untill the fight turns melee when the bayonets are pointed at eachother.

And I haven't even mentioned the historical battles that come with each Total War, you can reenact battles that actually took place and with a historically similar setting and armies to command. Pitching you as Washington vs the Brittish and many others. There is a demo available here on Steam, in it you can play at least one of these historical battles and get a glimpse of what is in store for you when it comes to battles, but if you like games like Civilization or RTS games like Age of Empires and you haven't tried Total War at all, you will love it!

reviewText:
Empire is one of the biggest Total War games you can get today. Spanning over about 1/3 of America, Europe and India.

Because of the huge scope you get a staggering 20+ factions in game minor and major nations. With a nice number of them been playable and with the hack or two you can play as them all.

The amount of nations means this is more of a challenge but the combat can be a bit stale. Unlike past game it’s all guns and odd melee combat as really, gun combat is simple with only a few tactics needed to give a clear victory.

This is the main down-turn of the game, the best part of the game has to be its small micromanagement system and upgrades for regions on the map and not in the city is a great addition, sometimes later in the game managing all this is hard but non the less rewarding to the dedicated player.

Huge map, plenty of factions and plenty of lands.

Downside: ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ diplomacy, a little bit overbearing for the average player. Stale combat.

Easily a 8.9/10

reviewText:
In my humble opinion, Empire: TW is the most ambitious installment in the TW series to date.  With almost the whole world as your playground, you are able to build or destroy empires that cover enormous areas.  Only a world on such a scale can truly capture the impressiveness of your achievements, helping you match the greatness of empires and kingdoms now of by-gone years.

That said, more up-to-date TW games have better battle mechanics and physics.  The battles themselves, whilst visually stunning, might sometimes leave you scratching your head as to why a perfectly placed unit didnt do what you hoped it would.  Things like line of sight are not as obvious in Empire.  The AI is probably as good as any other, although that isn't saying much.  Programming competitive AI in TW games must be a nightmare and is therefore going to always be a weak spot open for mass criticism.

Overall, despite the short comings described, the feel of Empire is arguably unique in the series.  It is one of the few games these days which isnt 'finished' within 10-20 hours.  You can still be playing this game after hundreds if not thousands of hours and seeing new experiences and creating new narratives (if that's your thing).

reviewText: Empire: Total War takes us away from the battlefields of both Ancient and Middle Aged Europe and Middle-East and takes us to the Empires of Europe during the 18th Century. Muskets and Cannon now determines who is the most powerful in all of Europe, Improved graphics and gameplay makes the game more exciting and stunning for Total War fans. Campaigns follow George Washington as he revisits the past from the development of Jamestown (1607), to the French and Indian War (1740's to 1750's), and to the American War of Independence (1775-1783). Not only can the battles between the European powers take place in Europe and the Middle-east, but also the Colonies of North America and South America and to the Colonies of India. Trade and expansion is key to your nation's victory, expanding out to colonies and your Empire's borders are crucial. The century turns to the the advancement of technology and development of new forms of Government. A time when the system of Monarchy seems to crumble while Republics and Democracies rise. Revolution and Colonization has made the 18th Century one of the world's most crucial centuries in all of the World's History. Will you reign or will you revoutionize a new Empire, the choice is yours. The times of Royal familes and difference in social class lays in your hands, will you preserve it or will you destroy it?

reviewText:
It's been a while since my first review of this game, so I felt it would be time to give out a more proper one. It's a good game, but not without several problems.

Empire: Total War, set in the 18th century, is a game I reccomend to the player who likes the idea of massive, 18th century-style land and naval battles. The game also has a very large campaign map, including India, Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and the Americas. There's also a lot of colonialism involved as well, so if you like all of these things I mentioned, you'll probably like this game.

However, don't expect multiplayer to be a fun experience. It's still active, but there aren't many people playing. There's a good number of players here that will mistakenly or purposefully break the rules set by players hosting their games. Even hosts will break their own rules.

You also need to consider the fact that there are many players on here that have adopted the use of specific units that are simply OP, which therefore ruins the historical atmosphere of this game. Historically, most 18th century infantry were armed with highly innacurate guns, so they gathered in very large formations and fired at each other. They were called line infantry. This type of warfare was in no way meant to prolong the life of an individual soldier at all. The entire point of this type of fighting between infantry units was to use overwhelming force and numbers of troops and firepower to overcome the other side, which meant that line infantry would have to have some serious discipline and toughness. You'd rarely ever take cover, and if you were in the front lines, your slim chances of surviving the battle depended on how fast you could reload your gun and if you could make your shot count before the other side did the same thing you were meant to do.

Now, you'd think line infantry would be the staple unit on this game, and therefore they'd be pretty effective in this game. However, their historical use as the essential staple unit for 18th century armies can easily be rendered useless on this game with just three types of units: Riflemen, skirmishers, and light dragoons.

The sad fact is that on multiplayer, the only three types of effective ground units that have any form of effectiveness on this game are the three units I stated above, aside from artillery. You see, the problem here is that skirmishers and riflemen have guns that can shoot farther than the muskets used by your line infantry, and they are unfairly accurate, meaning that your line infantry will be dropping like flies just trying to close the distance to take on the skirmishers and riflemen. They also reload their weapons incredibly fast. This is in no way historically accurate, because the guns used by lighter infantry forces at the time, no matter how far they shot, were still incredibly accurate and would have taken a long time to reload. Not only that, but we're talking about guns that weren't easy to aim with.

I could understand how lightly armed riflemen and skirmishers could give line infantry some serious trouble in, say, a bunch of forests, but they are so overpowered on this game that they can easily take out line infantry on an open battlefield.

Then there are light dragoons...

Light dragoons are soldiers riding on horseback, equipped with modified muskets that have shorter barrels. Therefore, they'd be less accurate, right? In real life, yes, but in this game? Wrong. Would it be easy reloading these guns on horseback? No, because muskets need to have the projectiles loaded with ram rods, primed, blah blah blah, shoot, repeat. It's difficult enough to do all of this while standing on your own two feet, but on horseback? That's bound to take longer.

Light dragoons can be incredibly dangerous to line infantry due to their superior speed, and because this game has overpowered them, every single soldier in a unit of light dragoons fires his gun, even the ones in the back. None of the troops in the front ranks of the dragoons die, and for some strange reason, a good number of the shots fired hit their mark. Sometimes, This means that you'll be having large numbers of line infantry dying all at once, which can cause a morale shock.

So unless you make rules against the use of light dragoons and skirmishers on the games you host in multiplayer, you'll be seeing these units being used on a constant basis, throwing all of the great historical accuracies of 18th century warfare out the window.

Now that's been explained, I should tell you about a few problems with other aspects of this game:

1) Despite the fact that Empire has a very large campaign map, you will be disappointed to find that almost every single battle map looks the same. Same texture, same everything. Yes, some buildings will look different depending on what part of the world you're in on the campaign, but you will quickly realise how bland the atmosphere of the maps are when you fight battles. Building detail in towns is also severly lacking.

2) The AI is incredibly dumb at times, so dumb that the developers decided to buff up the stats of the AI's units to compensate for their stupidity in the higher difficulty levels.

3) Individual troops in your army lack spatial awareness when they enter buildings or defend/attack fort walls in a siege battle. It's a horrid sight to see at times. Troops just move through each other in a frantic motion. Path finding on walls is also terrible.

4) Some sound effects for this game are awful, especially for muskets. For example, when a unit of line infantry fire a volley at the enemy, you only hear a 'poof' sound. These are primitive gunpowder weapons. They should be noisy and make a loud 'bang' when fired. Instead, the muskets used by your line infantry sound like fake guns used for movies in Hollywood.

5) You won't hear any general's speech before battle like you used to in Rome I and Medieval II.

6) There isn't much voice acting. You won't get to hear any voice acting at all when you initiate diplomacy, and the few bits of voice acting that you do here on this game tends to be subpar.

7) Melee combat between infantry units looks decent, but not amazing. The combat animations are too drawn out and look more rehearsed than realistic. Some of the combat animations are so terrible drawn out that everything looks unrealistic.

8) Because of the way the death animations work on this game, cavalry takes forever to take out a routing unit. Many times, an unnecessarily long combat animation has to be so terrible drawn out that it takes longer than needed for the cavalry to take out the routers. It'd be more convenient if the cavalry just swing their swords at boom, the routing units die faster.

9) Artillery units can be glitchy, even in multiplayer. Sometimes, they won't fire their guns no matter how many times you order them to.

10) On the campaign map, the AI controlling Britain, the United Provinces, and France tend to ignore India for some reason, so almost every single time you play this campaign, the Marathas end up becoming an OP faction.

11) There are no marching tunes with fifes and drums on the battlefield for any of the factions. This feature should have been implemented by the developers. I can understand that some players might find them distracting, but an option could be made to just turn off those marching tunes in the game.

12) Naval battles can sometimes be a little glitchy. Ships will sometimes move unnecessarily slow even when you order them to move faster.

This game can still be enjoyed despite all of these problems I mentioned. However, the it will never be as great as it could have been. There are, however, a few mods for this game that you can use to make this game more enjoyable. Keep in mind that the mods are, unfortunately, not supported for Steam as there is no workshop.

reviewText:
I think i reviewed this game shortly years ago so it's time to re-iterate when it's 100% sure no patches are coming.

Stay away. Unless
1) you get this very very cheaply.
2) and you have a zen-state mind where you just accept the the fact that 'you hit caca and caca does not hit you'. You need to loose all hope to begin with. Frustration leads to anger, anger leads to... well you know.

Prepare to constantly save and have a huge library of saves as sometimes without any warning 1-3 of your latest saves just becomes corrupted so you need to go back quite some time to be able to resume your game. Sometimes losing 5-10minutes of progress is a lot.

And before trying any mid-to-large sized battles you must exit the game and restart it just to ensure you have max memory available as the leaking kills the game soon. (4gb 32-bit win 7 here but according to forums it does not matter much)

Automatic quality settings is a must - not because of FPS - no no thats so pleb. for this game AQ is a defensive measure against crashes. Oh yeah, want to know what my secret sauce for getting both this game and Shogun 2 to work better when it's time to 'get real' and fight a big battle? put gfx settings to lowest. You MIGHT actualy be able to complete the game + save it (without corruption). It does not hurt though to have the will to play the same battle 2-5 times if it crashes.

Cheers. and here i just laugh at the idea of buying Rome 2. Never going to happen with any games based on this engine.

And to all of those people who have never been hit with these problems: good for you, the sun light shines on you but i don't want to know anything about that. I just don't. TW support  forums, the official and the unofficial ones are places where hope of getting things fixed goes to die.

I love this game to bits as can be seen by the hours clocked on it but playing it sure requires nerves of steel. I have never gotten even close to completing a short game. NOT EVEN CLOSE.  I'll put a thumbs up sign here next to this review so i dont get too much apologist comments. i dont want to hear them. No other game has ever caused more troubleshooting for me during the decades of gaming than this particular turd.

reviewText:
Empire quickly became my favorite strategy game over all.  I loved the details that went into the rendering of units, technologies and especially the accuracy of how those techs were used on the battle maps.

Naval combat is a particular love of mine.  I am a history major and love maritime history as well.  Being able to actually control the ships in line combat looks amazing,runs smoothly usually and is so much fun!

If there is a real problem it is the AI.  Diplomacy makes no sense really when a nation like the Maratha Confederacywill declare war on England for no reason that I can see.  In battles sometime the AI will move troops for no reason, it makes the battles a lot easier at times but does loose a bit to the challenge factor.

Over all Empire is my favorite game in the series and I hope everyone has a change to play.
best stragy game ever\n

This is without a doubt my favorite total war title and not just because I am a raging post-imperialist but conquering the jolly foreigner helps too.\nHuge map, clever new trade and diplomacy, limited but distinct units, epic land battles, new and devastatingly tricky sea battles and not to mention the grand strategy that we have come to know and love from the total war series and thats just before you mod it!\nI would seriously reccomend Darthmod total war, any flaws the game had are scrubbed off or made more bearable by this mod. Adding a whole new scale of land battles, innovative changes to the combat dynamic, vastly improved combat AI, even more shrewd and clever diplomacy, a huge new selection of units and a douzen other fixes this mod makes the game.
Anyone who likes TW games, buy it!!

So addictive. It may not be everyone's cup of tea but I recommend you try it out first, especially if you're interested in the time period. The campaign map is great and varied with Europe, America and India theaters.

This is a good strategy game, but for those of you who've not played any total war games previously, I recommend playing the game on easy mode. This is because there are a lot of faction who are able to gang up on you.

This game allows you to pick a faction and command their army. You can create a larger economy, and thus a bigger army to expand your operations.

You are able to partake in diplomatic relations to create trade deals and allies. Alternatively, you can use this feature to bribe your way out of 'sticky' situations, or you can even use it to declare war on another faction.

I would give this game a 7 and a half out of 10.

The above score would be higher if there were not a few flaws within this game, such as the unbalanced auto-resolve feature, and a few other things I can't be bothered to remember.
If your a fan of the civilazation series, I think you should get this game. You get to be sveral different countries and fight to conquer India Europe and the Americas.

Super game, HUGE campaign map, although it should have at least had 1 native American faction, but there is still more then enough to do. It has all the thing you would get in all of the earlier games.

Play with Darthmod Found on Total War centre (I can not recommend you not play without it as the game lacks all flavor), In the game you Create armies, diplomacy is involved and you require to manage your economy as well as political ambitions.
Trade is also a factor especially in the eastern trading company in the age of exploration and Colonisitation.
Generally speaking European factions have a lot more and slightly expensive guns and line infantry effective at range, poorer in hand to hand combat as the bulk of their forces as well as have to compete agaist other european powers.

Compared to that of indian/middle eastern troops that have lower morale but elephants, camels and swordsmen which use more hit and run tactics with larger amies similar to native Americans that can close the gap and defeat european armies which are more costly.

There are also Spys (rakes) and Technology involves (gentlemen) who can steal, assasinate and sabotage targets

Generals in your armies, and spies/rakes gain traits as they do more actions, Traits give permenent bonuses or negative atributes and some are quite funny like a mistress. You also have to watch how much industry you build because it effects the population and they may rebel as well as relion being involved taking a provience of another faith requires management and larger garrisons initially to make them submit and conform to your empire.

Without getting to much involved there is a lot of detail in this game and I highly recommend this as probally the best total war game arguably.

Near perfect game, ever amusing. If you're looking for a good 'ol RTS game  to amuse yourself, this is it!

This game is completely worth every penny in the price! This is a RTS fans dream come true!

Let me hit the highlights of this game:

The graphics and sound effects make it feel as if your actually in an 18th century army. When I get off the game, I sometimes feel as if Im getting out of a time machine, bringing myself back from the past, back to the present.

Building and researching takes a little figuring out and can be confusing, but you'll see things as you play. Completing the tutorial will also help.

On the Grand Campaign, it is CRITICAL you begin recruiting, and researching military stuff immediately. The easier the setting, the lesser the AI will attack you, but they'll come. My favorite faction is Prussia. However, when you first begin the Grand Campaign, there is a ton of factions. Even factions you cant choose from. Usually, around the fourth turn, Prussia and Austria declare war on each other, because they are close to each other and hostile towards the other. So, whichever faction you choose to be, be warned: the factions that are your neighbors are most likely to declare war against you.

Once you enter battle, your given time to setup your troops. If your using cannons, it is VITALE you set them up before the battle begins. They setup into firing position slow and can be moved slow. Very realistic, so it takes away any annoying feeling.

You will need to build navies. Those can be extra challenging. The cost of a single ship is extra high, so building a huge navy is slow. Its also pretty hard to have multiple huge navies at the same time. Although most helpful, usually its best to build a navy when your ready for use.

Naval battles are probably the most difficultest battle. The ships sail slowly. The AI usually starts in a single line, and spreads out, slowly, encircling your ships. These battles vary in time length, usually depending on who has the more battle ships. A variety of ships helps.

In the Grand Campaign, they also have notes mentioning historical events, such as Captain Kidd being hung, the start of circus's and much, much, much more.

When I tried an online multi player battle, I was in RTS gamers heaven. No matter the AI, playing against an opponent who thinks, is 100 times better. Especially when you win.

Overall, if anyone likes history, strategy, thinking, or strategy games, this game is for them! 100/10

This is a great strategy game like Medieval Total War was before. You will have some difficulties at the beginning but with a good strategy, diplomacy and money you will quickly start to rule the world and win this epic game.

Game:

Empire Total War is a wonderfully addictive game. The campaign is very well made and will soak up hours of your life as you try to dominte the entire world. You have many factions to choose from.  The battles are very fun, particuarly online, but are alot different then non gunpowder total wars. They seem a bit slower and less engaging. Still its very fun. Though not my fav TW game, I promise you it will entertain you for a long while. Especially if you like the time period.\n\nAll in all I give this game a 7/10

All great games, for me I would have to place this game at #2 to Medieval II Total War... Tons of content and story and endless hours or pure entertainment... I haven't even tried any of the mods yet but I'll get there when I start to feel the game is lacking as for now it's been years and they are all great games. Good luck, Happy Hunting...

Empire Total War is a strategic game based around the 1800s. where you control any of the major empires/countries during that time such as Great Britian, France, Prussia and the Ottoman Empire. You control the empires economy and military and research and you choose who to declare war on or who to make peace with. Any of the battles that your nation is in you can play and control your men.   :)

A few of my friends have said that they are unimpressed by this game when considering the other additions in the Total War franchise and mainly due to the broken A.I. I however find that in my experience the A.I. hasn't been to hindering, the cavalry have been utterly overhauled as underwhelming, even on the charge my best cavalry can get ruined charging the enemy line formations.

But for me this is ok, it reinforces my reliance on artillery and infantry using cavalry just to chase down enemies on the rout or in desperate circumstances hitting one flank of wavering enemy.

I only find one thing to be infuriatingly broken. Trade ports and having your trade routes raided via sea. no ammount of navy can prevent this, and a single boat being able to raid so much is ridiculous.

This does not take from my enjoyment of this game however.

As an avid total war fan I really like this game, however it has its fair share of issues, its loaded with bugs, battle influencing bugs which are quite the pain.  The AI is absolutley atrocious, when you engage in a seige battle, for example, the enemy will at times not attack you, as you sit in your fort unable to do anything and have to wait for the battle timer to run out, and well, if you dont have any battle timer set, you better hope you saved the game before that battle so you can get lucky and win with an auto-resolve.  Thats another thing, the auto resolve, it works just fine on land, but it is completely unusable in the water.  You get a decent chance of winning the battle, however you will suffer massive casulties.  For example, if I were to win a naval battle using auto resolve, I would have lost 3 of my Ships-of-the-Line, to a fleet of merchant ships, which is completly unrealisitic.  I should probably start talking about the good stuff, first off its FUN, like really fun, like really really really fun! Especially if you are a complete history nut like myself.  For the price of 20 bucks its awesome, I never bought the expansions, never thought it was neccassary the game is just fine without them and not worth the extra 15 bucks in my opinion.  Highly reccomend, great for price, the only thing is that Napoleon Total War, the newer installment has much better graphics, and less effective muskets, which coresponds to the time period quite well. Napoleon is less broad however, focusing only on Europe, no American or Indian theatures are availible. Hope this helped, if you can get around the bugs then you will learn to LOVE this game. BTW, you need a powerful computer to run it at max settings.
It is really fun to play.
Worth every penny it costs

reviewText: One of my favourite games, it is a very intreguing strategy game with some balance, however on the hardest diffuculty in the game after i have played a few campaigns i can conquer most of the world as the maratha confederacy, or just 10 territories as other nations. I like how it made the strengths of different countries realistic rather than balanced, it makes it so then there is another diffuculty scale; the nation you choose.

Good game with a unique trading system. Campaign map gameplay feels smooth and easy, with enough micro- and macromanagement to keep you entertained for a while. Combat however, is often awkward with non-responsive or slow responding troops, and sieges are a downright pain at times. Darthmod is a must-have, since it fixes a lot of battles. Naval battles are fun and rewarding, although they tend to get too messy and clustered when fighting with a large fleet against an equally large fleet. All in all, the game has many new and unique options never seen in gaming before, and I'd recommend trying it out if you like strategy games.

This is definately the best of the ,,Total war´´-Games,playing in 18th and 19th century..It also beats its successor,which is playing in the napoleonic conflicts,as i would say..
After playing more than 180 Hours for now,i can really recommend this game,as one of the best strategy-games,which are available at all..It's very dynamic in its battle-system,on land,or at sea,despite the fact,that the naval battles are sometimes a bit clumsy in the handling of the ships,but there are many types of weather and circumstances at sea battles,which are not just looking phenomenal,they are also taking influence in the ongoing of the battle..Such,you are in a great advantage,if the wind is blowing in the back at your sail for example,because you can start firing earlier, and you are also faster at all..But the Battles on Land are even the most impressive in that game,because they are providing a lot of opportunities mostly,by hiding units in forests,or just from distance to the enemy,if there's fog..The enemy is- And that's something which seems to be a very sheldom phenomene in Video games- Also able to gather tactical and strategical advantages,not just in superior manpower,but also in the experience and abilities of their Regiments and commanders. Also,the cavalry units of the enemy aren't just ordered into a wholeunit of pikemen,as they are now in Rome II..In Land battles,the infantry is,as in realisitc circumstances too,the Fundamental might of any army,providing the highest power,the most dynamic combat and abilities,and- of course-taking the most casaulties..As historical correctly (which is not the use in this game,as you can see as soon as the game starts,such as Sweden for example,is suddenly allied(!) with russia,during the time of the great nordic war,such as Great Britain can be played in 1700 (Founded in 1707) etc.), the Infantry regiments are mostly formed out of 160-200 Men,armed with muskets. The musket firing distance is also very realistic,and goes up to 70-100 meters at maximum,if fired by the line-infantry..Some units,armed with rifles,not with muskets,are useful by up to about 120 Meters in this game..Of course,any circumstances in battle are also taking influence onto the fighting spirit of the soldiers,which could also be enforced by elite units nearby,such as the general staff..Rainy weather causes Malfunctions of the muskets,because of an ineffectivity of gunpowder etc..It's a very time intensive,but then again,a great game,even despite the fact,it's not historically accurate at all.

Depending on,which era you want to play in,i really recommend this game and its successor,which is ,,Napoleon:Total war´´.

reviewerDisplayName: [S] K U R K E N
reviewText: Never gets bored of this shiieeet , a bit buggy

Took a long time but this game finally hooked me.  Here are the pros and cons:

Pros:
- Voice acting is EXQUISITE.

If you are multilingual, try playing one of the countries where you know their language.  The Tutons speak German, the Indians speak (what?  Hindi?), the Britians speak English with a British accent, and the Americans speak with an American accent.

- The tactical battles are very good.

This might also depend on what AI difficulty you choose - but at a normal difficulty tactical battles are interesting.  They might even be considered the core gameplay of the game, and avoiding them with autoresolve means far worse outcomes than playing them yourself.

- The quotes during loads are interesting reading

- The way the world is divided adds a new mechanic (instead of having one contiguous map)

This adds some confusion, but after understanding it the mechanic adds an extra dimension to the gameplay.

- Economic system is good


Cons:

- By now most TBS games have a consistent UI at least where outstanding tasks are concerned, but not Total War

If you forgot to move that unit who's been sitting idle for the last 3 turns - it's your fault.  You should have gone and looked at a book or something.  Or you should play Warlock or Civ or Fallen Enchantress or Endless Space because ALL of those games handle this exactly the same way with a list in the right column.

- Don't let the campaign turn you off.

It's not a great campaign, but at least there is one.  The downside is the campaign hides some of the goodness the game has to offer, and there are confusing moments at the very beginning where the tactical battle makes no sense.  [Not a good time to confuse players.  Devs, I recommend never" as the best time to confuse players.]

- Sea battles are just too realistic (which translates into boring)

I know I know... "It's realistic!  We went to some naval museum or whatnot and got accurate reproductions of these ships and the physics blah blah blah..."  We don't care.  Well I don't anyways.  Can't you put in a realism slider?  I'm used to ship handling like in Pirates!  And this is WAAAAY too slow even accelerated.

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Also
date: you can't really tell which of the various countries might resonate with you
recommended: so don't get turned off by the first country you try to play.  I played Britian for a while
hoursPlayed:
and then on a whim switched to playing India and loved it.  The best way is to experiment.

In all it's a satisfying game.

If you aren't absolutely sure it will play on your systme (and some people have seen crashes)

It's different than other TW games, but it's a refreshing change. Guns don't make the game less exciting, as some argue; instead, they require a change of tactics. Playing in the colonial era can actually be quite fun.
The graphics are an improvement, though they aren't great, but in this kind of game, I prefer gameplay over visuals. The gameplay is great - the world is gigantic, there is a new building system that makes building multiple structures simultaneously possible, there is a technology and philosophy research area, there are gentleman, naval battles where you can actually control your ships (I don't enjoy these much, though they look nice), there is North America and some of South America, and India (which we only got a glimpse of in Alexander!) There are many playable factions, and you can even unlock the American Indian factions by purchasing the Warpath DLC (this, again, requires a drastic change in strategy from the main ETW game, so buyer beware; it's probably also the only DLC worth buying, and only for a few bucks). Oh, and there's also the good ole US of A, which can be played in a campaign tracing the nation's development from a few settlers in Jamestown to an independent but vulnerable republic at the turn of the century.
A few cons: the game is a bit glitchy, battles usually take place in boring forts that all look the same instead of cities, cannon have limitless ammo (could be a pro), game can get slow with the sheer number of factions at the end of every turn.
The game came out very unfinished, but it's been polished up and is now defnitely worth buying for any TW fan.
Amzing game wait for it to go on sale tho last sale it was only a dollar
Anyone who likes TW games, buy it!!

Empire quickly became my favorite strategy game over all.  I loved the details that went into the rendering of units, technologies and especially the accuracy of how those techs were used on the battle maps.

Naval combat is a particular love of mine.  I am a history major and love maritime history as well.  Being able to actually control the ships in line combat looks amazing,runs smoothly usually and is so much fun!

If there is a real problem it is the AI.  Diplomacy makes no sense really when a nation like the Maratha Confederacywill declare war on England for no reason that I can see.  In battles sometime the AI will move troops for no reason, it makes the battles a lot easier at times but does loose a bit to the challenge factor.

Over all Empire is my favorite game in the series and I hope everyone has a change to play.

Empire Total War is one of the best games I have ever played. You can play this game in many ways like a Civization game with the campagin map but. It was A LOT of replay value since if you choose to play as a different nation they have comepletley different play styles, units, and diplomecy which makes two play throughs of Grand Campagin completley different. In combat however is where it really shines. The strategy is SO in depth about how to deploy your units, when to deploy your units, and what formation is extremly fun. It is also EXTREMLY detailed as you can zoom in and clearly see your units individually and watch them fight. My favorite part is to look after a big battle at the battlefield where you can look at all of the bodies bc they dont despawn and you can see where they were deployed and how bloody was the combat it is amazing, However the diplomecy can be annoying with the AI and they are kinda dumb but all is forgiven if you choose to go on hard and play the battles yourseld because that is where the focus is.

If you are new to the series this is one of the most realistic RTS games out there. I have seen on the Military History Channel a show called Deceisive Battles I believe it was called and they used Rome: Total War to simulate the battles with amazing accuracy. This game came out later than it

Amazing, realistic, and in depth gameplay would reccomend for people new to the strategy genre and strstegy veterans alike

Great game, great graphics, great histrical acuarce, great game. Good for people how like stratgy
very adictive game , awesome with darthmod

Sad to say but this game isn't that great. Mainly because of the AI, in a game were alliances and diplomacy are so essential, you'd think the AI would be great. Its the complete opposite. Allies won't help at all, city states that are allied to you at the start of the game drag you into wars with super powers you can't possibly win and if you break the alliance you lose ALL your allies, and everyone will hate you and go to war with you. Another thing, navies. Navies are very key to the game (as you can imagine) but sadly its very very hard to build one. You start off with no navy to speak of, while other countries (Spain, France) have many fleets. You can try to build a navy, but before its big enough another nation will come along and destroy it. Finally my last issue is up keep of armies. The game is called Total War for a good reason, you are always at war on multiple fronts (which is annoying as you have to put all your money into war and you can't improve your nation). Which means you will need multiple armies, which is hard at the start because your allies wont help and you will get bankrupt, your troops will leave you and you will get overrun. I have played this game alot (I got the game on a disk before I got it on steam hence the measly two hours on record) and have won world domination on hard difficulty. This game is playable but it will be one miserable ride.
However this some moments can be quite good, like when thousands of your cavalry charge down those damn rebels. And when you look over whole continents that belong to you. And when you finally crush filthy France and Spain for constantly hindering your progress. There are good moments and the tears, pain and self harm make it worth it. So maybe you should give it a go. I'm just some kid with too much time on my hands what do I know.

Final Verdict: 7/10

You might even learn a few things from the poignat qoutes from the rich and crazy over the years, to little known obscure events through the period 1700- onwards. Great Great Great. CoD lovers need not apply. Please, dont even think about it.

Overall a fine addition to the TW franchise. If buying this game in the year 2014, you'll find that most of the bugs have been fixed and you can play a pretty smooth game. I've played this on Xp and 7. I personally found the other TW games to be slightly,, better. But again that does not make this bad. Think of Chocolate Ice Cream being your favorite and this game is Vanilla. It's still good just not the best.\nThe sea battle's are insanely fun for some and horrid for others, but with the ability to just auto fight them, problem solved. I find the game lacks serious depth but that seems to be a problem that TW is just following and getting worse at. Diplomacy is pretty much a fail as is using religion. As a matter of fact this is probably the worst in the franchise but that's not saying much. Playing as India or Russia is a great fun challenge that's refreshing and different.\nIf you're a fan then yes this is a no brainer if you're new to this genre and this franchise, I'd recommend Medieval 2 or Shogun 2/Rome 2, any of the 2's I guess first but really you can't go wrong here.
Even for my pc the game is pretty heavy but the game is very fun to play with quite nice graphics and decent gameplay.\nThe multiplayer is dead though.
Good stuff.
the game is SOOOO FUN!!!

Pros:

+ Only TW to date that's in the gunpowder age
+ Naval combat is exciting and yet to be topped by the titles after it
+ Geographically the largest, and most diverse, TW game
+ Unit variety (gunpowder, melee, cavalry, artillery, etc) makes land combat more intricate and strategic
+ Introduced the tech tree
+ Agents are now more useful and have more impact on the campaign map

Cons:

- Very poor release debut (almost as bad as Rome 2: Total War)
- Naval combat does have some kinks
- No real depth for Generals and no Family Tree
- Dramatically limited modding compared to past titles

The Bottom Line

Creative Assembly took quite a risk with Empire: Total War.

The franchise up to this point was firmly rooted in the melee combat eras of warfare and the concept of adapting the gameplay to anything after 15th century Europe seemed like an unappealing and potentially problematic idea.

To a degree those reactions weren't quite baseless when the game finally released with an unhealthy amount of performance and technical issues but once those started to get hammered out and players started getting into the meat of the game the experience turned out to be quite enticing.

As with all Total War games however the experience the player gets out of the game is highly reliant on whether or not the time period is personally appealing. Those who find the 18th century interesting will obviously find a lot to love here but those uninterested may move on fairly quickly.

8 musketballs out of 10

best total war ever in my opinion. this game is even better with Darthmod ;)\n

As an avid total war fan I really like this game, however it has its fair share of issues, its loaded with bugs, battle influencing bugs which are quite the pain.  The AI is absolutley atrocious, when you engage in a seige battle, for example, the enemy will at times not attack you, as you sit in your fort unable to do anything and have to wait for the battle timer to run out, and well, if you dont have any battle timer set, you better hope you saved the game before that battle so you can get lucky and win with an auto-resolve.  Thats another thing, the auto resolve, it works just fine on land, but it is completely unusable in the water.  You get a decent chance of winning the battle, however you will suffer massive casulties.  For example, if I were to win a naval battle using auto resolve, I would have lost 3 of my Ships-of-the-Line, to a fleet of merchant ships, which is completly unrealisitic.  I should probably start talking about the good stuff, first off its FUN, like really fun, like really really really fun! Especially if you are a complete history nut like myself.  For the price of 20 bucks its awesome, I never bought the expansions, never thought it was neccassary the game is just fine without them and not worth the extra 15 bucks in my opinion.  Highly reccomend, great for price, the only thing is that Napoleon Total War, the newer installment has much better graphics, and less effective muskets, which coresponds to the time period quite well. Napoleon is less broad however, focusing only on Europe, no American or Indian theatures are availible. Hope this helped, if you can get around the bugs then you will learn to LOVE this game. BTW, you need a powerful computer to run it at max settings.
If your a fan of the civilazation series, I think you should get this game. You get to be sveral different countries and fight to conquer India Europe and the Americas.

Incredibly fun, intriguing, and smart. Its rated among the top strategy games of all time. You can spend hours and hours building and upgrading your empire, taking over nations, creating and managing political affairs, theres a lot to do. This game is a must play for real strategy fans.

reviewText:
an immersive game plagued with bugs, but strikes back with fantastic gameplay, il fill out a little list,

Pro:

research tree is large and can jump to whatever and keep you're previous research status.

Unit selection.

diplomatic relationships.

aggressive/defensive AI combat always delivering fresh gameplay.

region development.

Unit-tactics and detail.

ship variety and detail.

the AI is random, it might be an ally 1 game to other-nations, new game it might be invading them and pilaging them for worthy loots, ETC trade, cash, resources or just schools to invade you later..yes..they're coming for you.....

the unexpected can happen, you may be, ooh lets say austria, and you're just peacefully minding you're business when BAM, sweden, prussia or Poland or some other nation declare you unfit for you're throne and engage in a war of succession ultimatly initiating war, sure you could just peace-bribe them with you're money...but thats an insult you won't let pass...will you?....

Cons:

unit-selection, yes its pretty-much a mix, the unit selection is variable, 1 nation will be given unique units where another is left-bland and utterly outmatched.
l
ack of playable factions.

the AI has no sense of island invading, making island defence pointless.

cavarly, they are utterly hopeless in late-game, the AI will spam square-formations to heck and back it up with either long-range troops in forests or (rarely-late-Late game wise) mortars.

diplomacy, another mix, its fun, but the AI will sometimes decline something that they should not refuse and is TO GOOD TOO REFUSE...yes they would give up a million even if its something simple like research.....

trade, while if you own half the world, you'l be FILTHY RICH...but early game the AI is utterly horrid, they will never develop more trade-ports leaving normally profitable resources for everybody, unused.

certain factions ETC indian nations(America) are just buffers, you can utterly steamroll them with line-infantry and even god-awful cavarly straight from early-game because they lack anyform of effective resistance besides militia spam and skirmishing which, still utterly fails.

RESULT
overrall id give it a 8/10 because its fun and always keeps me entertained cus the AI always do something unexpected and sometimes frustrating where you're likeyou just did that?!

Recently in my playthrough playing as France (and doing quite well I might add) I tried to get on the good side of the surrounding powerful nations such as Spain and Britain. So my main objective was trying to gain land without the threat of being mass murdered, I did many other attacks on smaller nations such as the native americans and indians (not racist, but they are really weak) and gained quite a bit of land as well as keeping hostilities in Europe, all happy and friendly. I gained quite a bit of power as I built my armies, gaining more and more elite soldiers along with maitaining my budget, as well as with keeping up with the new technology (like your hip parents try to do). I was doing more than fine now and rekted everyone in North America leaving only me and the 13 colonies, which was now taken over by Britain. I didn't want to start a war equalivent to what a modern-day nuclear war would look like, and would rather avoid turning my ETW into a Fallout game.\nAnyway, back on track, I rekted North America and went back to home sweet Europe. After a few turns, a war broke out between Hannover and Westphilia and I happened to be allied with Hannover. You'll know Westphilia is directly east of France if you play the game, and so I was basically about to crush another metaphoric pebble with my big French boot. So I go and send about 1700 men to besiege it, and another army of about 1500 just in case anything went wrong against the 1600 Westphilian men defending the capital, and proceeded to crush them sustaining barely any casualties other then a small light infantry regiment retreating. Well, I successfully commited genocide wiping them off the face of the Earth and laughed when the A Region Has Been Defeated" message appeared. I was in a good mood for obvious reasons
date: and decided to generously handed over the Westphilia territory to the monsters who started the small Holocaust. Hannover. Everytime I play this game I will remember that mistake. I gave them the territory and was slapped in the face with the harshest words ever spoken in the 1700's

reviewText: best stragy game ever\n

This is without a doubt my favorite total war title and not just because I am a raging post-imperialist but conquering the jolly foreigner helps too.\nHuge map, clever new trade and diplomacy, limited but distinct units, epic land battles, new and devastatingly tricky sea battles and not to mention the grand strategy that we have come to know and love from the total war series and thats just before you mod it!\nI would seriously reccomend Darthmod total war, any flaws the game had are scrubbed off or made more bearable by this mod. Adding a whole new scale of land battles, innovative changes to the combat dynamic, vastly improved combat AI, even more shrewd and clever diplomacy, a huge new selection of units and a douzen other fixes this mod makes the game.
Anyone who likes TW games, buy it!!

reviewText: Я очень люблю стратегии из серии Total War особенно Shogun и Shogun 2. Это игра мне понравилась больше всех других. В этой игре есть всё что и в прошлых частях но добавлено тоже очень много. Например: можно выходить в море... и т.д.

Empire Total War.

First of all, Empire Total War is the first Total War title to feature naval battles (which I suck at). But the community had been asking for this for ages. So, I'm glad it finally came to be.

Gameplay wise. The battles are fun weather it be a massive battle for control of a nations capitol or a small skirmish to harass an enemy force. The campaign map is massive in size and would take ages to fully conquer (Most I ever got was 75% or so). Two things I dislike about this game is the A.I pathing and the A.I. politics. When it comes to pathing its okay and I get it can be hard to do with units made up of a hundred men but when of these men get stuck trying to walk through a cart its brutal. For some reason when one guy gets stuck the whole unit looses the ability to move, shoot, or follow orders properly. Then the politics. The computers are down right awful at times you can offer then every cent you have for one piece of tech and they'd decline.

Other those two details its a great game. The massive scale, the awesome battles, the variety of units, the tactics, the maps, the world map all work together to make a great game.

Despite having major issues in the begining, crashing, bugs etc, I really enjoyed playing this game. Like the other Total War games it has a mix of a turn based campaign map where you build up your Cities, Towns, Infrastructure and strategicaly move your troops. Real-Time battles from Open Fields and Seiging Forts to Sea Battles with fleets of heavy first rate ships of the line.

Still the game has issues but they can be looked past, because who doesn't love conquering enemy nations with several stacks of doom".

Pros :
Game looks great on high graphics settings.
Sound is Great.
Great Ship battles with a veriety of ships.
3 different Continents to conquer - Americas
date:
Europe and India.
Large open fields to fight on with large army's.
Historical Battles.
Able to save presets for troop selection (Multiplayer and custom battles).
Different victory conditions.
Multiplayer
recommended:
though you don't really see any games on it any more (luckily all the achievments are soloable against the AI).

Cons :
Diplomacy needed alot more work
hoursPlayed: AI can be completely stupid when it comes to the negotiations asking for rediculas things.\nAI on open field battle needed a bit more work

reviewText:
I had played Rome TW (brilliant) and Medieval 2 TW (also brilliant) for a good few years before trying Empire.  I was unsure whether the radical transition in technology would still offer gameplay I found interesting which is why I put it off for some while.  The RTS battles are indeed completely different and took a while to get used to but the learning curve itself was very enjoyable and it doesn't take long to get used to the different fighting style.

The large campaign map, while daunting at first, is the perfect next step in a TW game and there is great satisfaction to be had in nuturing a faction from humble begginings to a mighty empire.

The sea battles are very fluid and surprisingly realistic for The Creative Assembly's first attempt (I have not tried Napoleon TW, not sure how the two compare on this front).

My only issue with Empire TW is that there is a step away from the intricate historical detail shown in previous titles.  Rome TW and Medieval 2 TW were both very educational in a passive, subliminal kind of way.  It was almost impossible not to learn about the time period and this is something I loved.  Empire TW does not have this to quite the same extent (still above and beyond most other strategy titles) which is not likely to be an issue to most as I imagine most aren't even interested in this factor (maybe I need to get out more?).

Anyway, this game is an impeccable title in a brilliant francise.  I picked this up together with Shogun 2 TW in an offer around £7 and if this is available for a price under £15 it is well worth it.  Even if you are not a fan of startegy games, picking this up when on offer is an absolute must.

Oh, and try Rome TW and Medieval TW as well!  Good day!

Honestly, I got this gme for the sea battles. After some research and after enjoying Medieval 2, I  thought the sea battles would be extremely neat in additon to the land battles. I was right, the sea battles are awesome, there is a tree of technology, which you can steal from rivals, you get to conquer the new world and Iindia,or if you are not into the world domination thing, you can play as the young america, fighting for thier independace, from Great Britian. In short This game is awesome.

reviewText:
I'm almost breaching playtime of 1000 hours. After all this time, Empire never fails me. It has had a buggy release, a bumpy start... but I've not played the same amount of time on any other Total War game. Why? Because Empire: Total War has an immense replayability, lots of factions, a great modding community with a large variety of mods, a whole century to play in and half the world as a map. It's a game you'll come back to. I know the Total War fanbase is often divided in those that favour melee like Medieval, Rome... and those that have a soft spot for the muskets. I'm with the latter, but give it a shot. It's a versatile game.

Also, I'd like to recommend Napoleon: Total War, but where it excels in graphics and gameplay over Empire, it lacks replayability. I, for one, shall always return to Empire for a couple of extra hours of fun. Be it now, or in days or weeks, I'll play this game.

To end, I'd like to underline the fact that the uniforms of this era are made to outfab the opponent. Yes, that's right, no plain, boring khakis for this man. I find the lack of fab in today's warfare... disturbing.

an immersive game plagued with bugs, but strikes back with fantastic gameplay, il fill out a little list,

Pro:

research tree is large and can jump to whatever and keep you're previous research status.

Unit selection.

diplomatic relationships.

aggressive/defensive AI combat always delivering fresh gameplay.

region development.

Unit-tactics and detail.

ship variety and detail.

the AI is random, it might be an ally 1 game to other-nations, new game it might be invading them and pilaging them for worthy loots, ETC trade, cash, resources or just schools to invade you later..yes..they're coming for you.....

the unexpected can happen, you may be, ooh lets say austria, and you're just peacefully minding you're business when BAM, sweden, prussia or Poland or some other nation declare you unfit for you're throne and engage in a war of succession ultimatly initiating war, sure you could just peace-bribe them with you're money...but thats an insult you won't let pass...will you?....

Cons:

unit-selection, yes its pretty-much a mix, the unit selection is variable, 1 nation will be given unique units where another is left-bland and utterly outmatched.
l
ack of playable factions.

the AI has no sense of island invading, making island defence pointless.

cavarly, they are utterly hopeless in late-game, the AI will spam square-formations to heck and back it up with either long-range troops in forests or (rarely-late-Late game wise) mortars.

diplomacy, another mix, its fun, but the AI will sometimes decline something that they should not refuse and is TO GOOD TOO REFUSE...yes they would give up a million even if its something simple like research.....

trade, while if you own half the world, you'l be FILTHY RICH...but early game the AI is utterly horrid, they will never develop more trade-ports leaving normally profitable resources for everybody, unused.

certain factions ETC indian nations(America) are just buffers, you can utterly steamroll them with line-infantry and even god-awful cavarly straight from early-game because they lack anyform of effective resistance besides militia spam and skirmishing which, still utterly fails.

RESULT
overrall id give it a 8/10 because its fun and always keeps me entertained cus the AI always do something unexpected and sometimes frustrating where you're likeyou just did that?!

reviewText: Excellent game, It makes you wanna learn about 18th century Europe!

If you're a sucker for 18th century warfare then this is the definitive game for you. Conquer, annihilate and rule as you build up your nation and its armed forces, trying to stay one step ahead of your adversaries both technologically and economically. Change history, why not make a Swedish colonial empire? Or a Russian North Africa? Perhaps conquer India as Prussia, all of these are scenarios which you can play out in Empire: Total War.


This is my all time favourite strategy game, and for the absolute ultimate experience, it should be played with DarthMod.

The game is not without its faults however, the campaign AI might declare war on you even though you have excellent relations with that particular country, the battle AI isn't always the smartest. Regiments won't fire unless every single man has fallen into formation, if even one man is stuck behind a tree a hundred yards away and the enemy is marching on them, they will not fire unless the last man is present in formation.

All in all, if you like this era of history or even have just a slight interest in it, then I recommend this game strongly.

Empire Total War.

First of all, Empire Total War is the first Total War title to feature naval battles (which I suck at). But the community had been asking for this for ages. So, I'm glad it finally came to be.

Gameplay wise. The battles are fun weather it be a massive battle for control of a nations capitol or a small skirmish to harass an enemy force. The campaign map is massive in size and would take ages to fully conquer (Most I ever got was 75% or so). Two things I dislike about this game is the A.I pathing and the A.I. politics. When it comes to pathing its okay and I get it can be hard to do with units made up of a hundred men but when of these men get stuck trying to walk through a cart its brutal. For some reason when one guy gets stuck the whole unit looses the ability to move, shoot, or follow orders properly. Then the politics. The computers are down right awful at times you can offer then every cent you have for one piece of tech and they'd decline.

Other those two details its a great game. The massive scale, the awesome battles, the variety of units, the tactics, the maps, the world map all work together to make a great game.

reviewText: Well dispite constant bugs ni the AI\nits ok i guess
This game offers a very smooth feeling of that you are in control of an entire army, but being a general does mean that you have to make some wise dicisions during your command.

By far the best total war since the original. Huge scale, big improvments to unit fighting and the time period of the units works well with this style of game play. It's much less...involved than the all melee ones. You're not constantly reogranizing formations or chasing units all over the map.

Absolutely fun! This game is very instructive, but this is very hard, too, especially at the beginning. But when you learn how to play, you can't practically stop playing.
Campaign is very entertaining and interesting. You can choose empire from year 1700, and do whatever you want. You can raid trade routes, wage war against other countries and conquer them. You can develop new technology, make massive army/navy and upgarde buildings like farms, for examble.
You can play Battle, too. This mode is only for battles against CPU or other players. You can develop your tactics in war and get the great feeling of massive victory.
I recommend this game for players who are interested in Strategy games. This is elite of Total War -series and all Strategy games. Price of this game is suitable. If you like Strategy, you can play this practically 100+ hrs, so 19,99 € isn't big price. And if you are interested in, buy all DLCs. They are so cool and make this game even better.
Thank you for reading, hope this helped you if you weren't sure, do you buy this or not!
4,5/5

reviewText: It is a great game BUY IT
This game is an absolute must have! Combining this game with great mods like Darth Mod or Minor Factions makes this game an incredible experience. This has got to be my favourite Total War game.
Having the French take over the world.

Fun world domination. Once the wars get old or slow, just overwhelm and auto resolve combat. Take a weak nation, and eventually own all of Europe, the Americas, Noarth Africa, Middle East, Russia, and India. Lots of infrastructure upgrades. Making allies, keeping them, dealing with enemies, and the killing allies is what this game is about. Diplomacy, War, Nation Building, and Strategy. Great all around, until you finally beat it, or take over most of the world. After that, it sits in your libraru untouched like most other games.

Good game for RTS fans if you love Nepoliananic history, weather its cannons or full on ship battles you can rise up and big an Army to conquer the world, good multiplayer conquest with friends defiently recommend this game.

It certainly is a very fun game, but taks a lot of time and dedication IMO. Easy settings you can roll over the world, the others are very pasisve. Higher difficulties though are challanging enough to be fun.\n\nI recommend this to every strategy game/history enthusiast.
